column5: Patriotism and other mistakes.
column12: Kateb, George: William Nelson Cromwell Professor of Politics, Emeritus, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, US
column13: (2006). Patriotism and other mistakes. xxxv, 422 pp. New Haven, CT, US: Yale University Press; US.
column21: (from the jacket) George Kateb is one of the most respected and influential political theorists of the past quarter century. His work stands apart from that of many of his contemporaries and resists easy summary. In these essays, Kateb often admonishes himself, in Socratic fashion, to keep political argument as far as possible negative: to assert what we are not, and what we will not do, and to build modestly from there some account of what we are and what we ought to do. Drawing attention to the nonrational character of many motives that drive people to construct and maintain a political order, he urges greater vigilance in political life and cautions against "mistakes" such as patriotism, which too often results in terrible brutality and injustices. He asks us to consider how commitments to ideals of religion, nation, race, ethnicity, manliness, and courage wind up in the service of immoral ends, and he exhorts us to remember the dignity of the individual. The book is divided into three sections. In the first, Kateb discusses the expansion of state power (including topics such as surveillance) and the justifications for war recently put forward by American policy makers. The second section offers essays in moral psychology, and the third presents fresh interpretations of major thinkers in the tradition of political thought, from Socrates to Arendt. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

Craig, C. Samuel

Craig, C. Samuel: Stern School of Business, New York University, New York, NY, US

column13: International Marketing Review. Vol.23(3), 2006, pp. 322-342.
column16: Emerald Group Publishing Limited; United Kingdom
column21: Purpose: To develop a more thorough understanding of culture in a rapidly changing global environment. Design/methodology/approach: The recent literature dealing with ways in which cultural dynamics are influencing the nature and meaning of culture are examined. Different perspectives of culture related to three key components of culture, intangibles, material culture and communication, are explored. Based on this, directions for research on the content of culture are discussed as well as how it should be approached. Findings: Culture is becoming increasingly deterritorialized and penetrated by elements from other cultures. This is resulting in cultural contamination, cultural pluralism and hybridization. It has become more difficult to study culture as it is becoming diffuse. At the same time, it is becoming more important to study it because of its pervasive influence on consumer behavior. Research limitations/implications: Given that culture is no longer a phenomenon defined by and isolated to a particular locale, research on culture must carefully specify the role of culture, define the appropriate unit of analysis, isolate confounding influences and expand the range of contexts. Originality/value: The parallel trends of globalization and multiculturalism make it increasingly important to develop a deeper understanding of culture and its various manifestations. For progress to be made, research designs must account for this complexity and span multiple contexts to establish the generality of findings. This will result in improved knowledge of culture and its role in molding consumption behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Art and Consciousness--The Pedagogy of Art and Transformation. [References].
column12: Grady, Michael: John F. Kennedy University, Orinda, CA, US
column13: Visual Arts Research. Vol.32(1,issue62), 2006, pp. 83-91.
column21: The world has changed profoundly in the past 50 years, but our approaches to educating artists have not. This paper describes the evolution and unique educational approaches of the Department of Arts and Consciousness at John F. Kennedy University in California - a studio art program that uses innovative holistic techniques to lead students into the integration of body, mind, spirit and culture, through art. The program stresses cross-cultural awareness, community service and spiritual awareness. The historical and cultural foundations for the re-emergence of art as a non-religious, spiritual, and self-integrative practice are examined. These foundations include ideas associated with the Bauhaus, Asian art and the Automatist branch of the Surrealist movement. The department's educational philosophies and curriculum are discussed within the context of overlooked spiritual legacies of modernism, cultural pluralism, and the changing roles of art as professional practice. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column21: Review three books "The Psychology of Cultural Experience," edited by Carmella C. Moore and Holly F. Mathhews (2001), "A History of Ancient Psychiatry," by Giuseppe Roccatagliata (1986) and "Pathologies of the West," by Roland Littlewood (2002). The first book, The Psychiatry of Cultural Experience, provides an anchoring platform for a cultural psychiatry. It lays the theoretical basis for a cultural psychology and it might consist of. It does so by illustrating the pervasive and insinuating way in which culture burrows into the mind and shapes what an individual feels, believes, orients to group mates, and how he or she acts out his or position in a society. While not addressing basic parameters of psychiatric conditions, chapters nonetheless strongly suggest that character is likely to be shaped and molded by culture. This book provides one with material with which one can make inferences about how psychiatric conditions are likely to be constructed psychologically and socially. The second book, A History of Ancient Psychiatry, reviews in a broad sweep the ideas and formulations the about human phenomena we now construe as mental illness or psychiatric disorder during the formative period of European history. While predominantly conceptual, theoretical, and historical, it provides nonetheless an opening for one to propose how "real persons" burdened by emotional and social problems were thought about and dealt with by the literate elite or experts. Furthermore, insofar as the latter produced knowledge out of clinical encounters, engaged their clients (or patients, apprentices) in dialogues, and the knowledge they produced percolated through (perhaps restricted) segments of the population, this book provides a view of how persons burdened by psychiatric-related conditions behaved and made sense of their predicament, and also how indigenous psychiatry was conceptually organized during antiquity and handled through forms of healing. The diversity of views, the cultural pluralism inherent in the configuration of psychiatric conditions and indigenous psychiatry, is analyzed and categorized. The third book, Pathologies of the West, brings one to the present and illustrates the maturity that the field of interest--cultural psychiatry--has attained. It discusses in detail "real" syndromes, describing not only how culture configures them as symbolic entities, expressive entities, but also as social and historical realities. The influence of psychiatry as an intellectual as well as medical institution in modern society is made abundantly clear by a creative examination of culture and modern social and intellectual history. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: In a psychoanalytic interpretation, the article explores the strand of thinking stimulated by the events of September 11th and how racism and religious prejudice are seen as an obstacle. Today we live in a global village, and the twin towers may have been a most potent symbol of humankind's progress in sharing a basic humanity in a way that supports each to grow and develop in their own way. However, this description is of life in the metropolitan West, where progress towards cultural pluralism has gone remarkably smoothly. Cities today are increasingly multi-cultural and tolerant, and sometimes proud of it. The author wonders have the privileged few, in global terms, achieved this by projecting the uncertainties and anxieties connected with ordinary human frailty into excluded groups around the world, whose lives then become less precious than our own. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: The article offers a socio-historical analysis of the evolution of Quebec school system since the 1960s. It puts forward that during the socio-ideological debates which began after World War II, the Parent report (1963-1965) has lead to the abandonment of the educational model based on the example of France and centred on classical humanities, but also driven by neothomist approaches. Through several changes of curricula and due to social and economic evolution, this educational model was progressively replaced by a more pragmatic one, focused on the adaptation to the economic and utilitarianist expectations of the neoliberal system. This transformation was supported by leading ideological views which evolved from humanities-based humanism to a renewed type of humanism: pluralist humanism - which was presented as being transhistorical since it maintained the continuity between both models - then to a humanist pedagogy and, finally, to cultural pluralism. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column21: Reviews the video, One Nation Many Voices by E. Ornstein and H. Moses (2004). This 56-minute video with accompanying guidebook, tells the story of the Brown County Diversity Resolution or the "English Only Law." The video makes the point that for many ethnic communities, there is a danger that their cultural heritage will be lost if fewer and fewer members of the next generation speak the language. The current trend is toward cultural pluralism where individuals can embrace certain American customs while maintaining a strong sense of their ethnic and cultural identity. The video illustrates this trend by highlighting a school program in Brown County, where Anglo and Latino students are learning Spanish and English simultaneously and where on alternating days one language is dominant. The video and guidebook are useful for school social workers, teachers, and administrators. The video also addresses the complex issues around loss of language, identity, and cultural connections. The video's narrative focus reflects a postmodern sensibility, which emphasizes the cultural context and the uniqueness of each individual's ethnic heritage. Overall, we found this to be a provocative and interesting video that encouraged us to examine our own biases and feelings about issues such as the immigrant experience, cultural pluralism, language, and bilingual education. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: Reviews the book, "Worship and Wilderness: Culture, Religion, and Law in Public Lands Management," by Lloyd Burton. While the author's account distances itself from the conventional, these are all indices of the degree to which this work is over-determined by a desire fully formed within a dominant national imaginary. In a sense, this book makes no bones about this insofar as the historical and other chapters that frame the contemporary case studies to which nearly half of this work is devoted are cast in terms of the First Amendment, the "trust doctrine" in U.S. Indian law, religious and cultural pluralism, and multiculturalism. It is, I suggest, such a formulation of the problematic at stake in the geography the author takes up, and the attendant Americanist ideology of the separate spheres occupied by religion and law, that predict the author's desire to locate nonnative religious-cultural claims alongside their native corollary and discover "coevolution" in these terms. If these American discourses are anything but irrelevant, as his cases and the works hovering in their margin suggest, they form but one discursive layer necessary to critically mapping the mutually constituted geography he has called up. As to this map's configuration, these scenes from the margin bring home law's simultaneities as a colonial-postcolonial site of encounter as the key to framing the more-than-raced histories of difference and democracy in indigenous America/America and beyond. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: Traditional citizenship education paradigms are inherently state-centered, because they overly emphasize teaching and learning about the structure and functions of government. Their goals have been limited to a nationalist agenda and are inadequate for preparing active, thoughtful, and caring citizens. In an increasingly interdependent and global world, there is an urgent need for reconceptualization of citizenship and the formulation of a new citizenship education paradigm. This new paradigm should redefine good citizenship, underscoring cosmopolitan values of human rights, social consciousness, cultural pluralism, global peace, and cross-cultural deliberation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: An exploration of relationships between cultural awareness, white racial consciousness, and referrals to child study teams.
column12: Fierstien, Jocelyn Renee: Rutgers The State U New Jersey, Graduate School Of Applied And Professional Psychology, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.64(9-B),2004, pp. 4676.
column21: This study investigated cultural awareness and White racial consciousness (WRC) among elementary faculty members, and their correlations with Child Study Team referrals in a New Jersey school district known to have high percentages of minority students. Faculty members were assessed during a weekly staff meeting to determine levels of cultural awareness on the Teacher Multi-Cultural Attitude Survey (TMAS; Ponterotto, Baluch, Greig, & Rivera, 1998), the Oklahoma Racial Attitude Scale (GRAS; LaFleur, Leach, & Rowe, 2002, in press), and demographic questionnaires. Data from 99 staff members at three schools were analyzed. Demographics revealed 86% of teachers as White and female, and approximately 50% had received no or minimal diversity training. The TMAS was used to determine the degree to which teachers perceived themselves as aware and comfortable with issues of cultural pluralism. Self reported cultural awareness was significantly lower than expected. The construct of WRC as used in this study consists of characteristic attitudes people have regarding the significance of being White and what that implies to those who do not share White group membership (Rowe, Bennett, & Atkinson, 1994). The majority of respondents identified as having Achieved White racial consciousness attitudes, although 23% of the scores were disregarded. Significant correlations, were found between WRC Integrative/Dominative and Reactive subscales and cultural awareness. WRC Conflictive scores negatively correlated with cultural awareness scores. Significantly higher cultural awareness scores were found when teachers had prior extensive diversity training as compared to teachers who had no training. This study revealed a significant correlation between Child Study team academic referrals and Integrative/Dominative scores. Other significant correlations between referrals and cultural awareness or WRC cluster scores were not found. Results are discussed and future areas of research are suggested. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 2004, Vol 49(6), 756-759. Review of book Why Do Men Barbecue? Recipes for Cultural Psychology by Richard A. Shweder (see record 2003-00366-000). This lucid, engaging, splendidly written book discusses issues of the utmost social and scientific relevance with passion and courage. Defending a pluralist conception of culture, presenting moral worlds encountered in field studies, and rejecting tacit or explicit beliefs of Western superiority are the main aims of Shweder's discourse. Against those moral activists who seem to possess too firm a sense of what is objectively and universally right or wrong. Shweder claims that different cultures should be considered equal in dignity. Shweder's defense of cultural pluralism is illuminating and courageous but seems to rely on an idea of culture as too fixed and self-contained to acknowledge the positive role that agency and moral activists can play in promoting change across different moral worlds. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: It is a fundamental ideal of liberal democracy that all citizens should enjoy fully equal citizenship. Yet many minorities are still routinely ignored, excluded, patronized, and not regarded as full members of the political community. This denial of equal standing undermines their equal citizenship. Liberalism and Cultural Pluralism each advocate strategies to improve this situation. Their arguments build upon expectations about how citizens should, can, and do understand membership in the political community. Our survey and focus group data from six matched communities in the United States and Great Britain show how citizens' understandings of membership in the political community incorporate communitarian attitudes that impede the liberal and cultural pluralist projects. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column13: Applied Psychology: An International Review. Vol.53(3), Jul 2004, pp. 400-422.
column21: Predictors and components of attitudes toward multiculturalism were studied in 341 native Dutch people. Attitudes were found to have a unidimensional structure, but the level of support for multiculturalism was found to vary significantly over societal domains. Level of education and living in city districts with few non-natives were the only background variables that were (positively) related to support for multiculturalism. A path model, with psychological background variables (knowledge, life satisfaction, life opportunities, perceived social norms about multiculturalism as a threat and support for multiculturalism, and social desirability) predicting attitudes and behavior, showed a good fit. Generally, exclusionist positions were not endorsed by majority Dutch, but cultural pluralism was not seen as a valuable asset of their society, and they are not inclined to put much effort into minority integration. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: Nationalist discourse and the ultra-conservative press in contemporary Poland: A case study of Nasz Dziennik.
column12: Starnawski, Marcin: Wroclaw University's Institute of Sociology, Poland
column13: Patterns of Prejudice. Vol.37(1), Mar 2003, pp. 65-81.
column21: After the democratic transition to post-Communist Poland, ultraconservative groups found themselves legitimately able to propagate a nationalist ideology. They focused on an idea of 'national identity' that clearly and restrictively defined the boundaries of the national community. In the late 1990s a far-right movement supported by a radical faction of the Roman Catholic Church gained wide public support and, eventually, political legitimization. The fears of those for whom the transition of the socio-economic system did not bring a change for the better have been exploited by activists and institutions that consistently point to various foreign 'threats' (external and internal) against Poland's political and economic independence and against national integrity. Starnawski analyses forms of anti-pluralist backlash as strategies undertaken by the ultra-conservative media. Provided is a case study of Nasz Dziennik, one of the major Polish newspapers to disseminate a far-right discourse that combines a concept of 'national identity' with radical Catholicism. Such nationalist-oriented media use rhetoric that claims to be representative of the dominant group, and attempt to provide the audience with a restrictive sense of identity that is based on the construction of elements that are considered foreign and threatening to a sense of nationhood, a mobilization of the audience against foreign 'threats', and the exclusion or marginalization of elements depicted as incongruous with collective identity, especially the cultures of national and ethnic minorities (both 'native' minorities and recent immigrants), minority religions and alternative cultures, as well as liberal advocates of diversity. Since Polish society is in large part culturally homogeneous, its members are more often exposed to stereotyped images of minority groups than they are to face-to-face contact with members of minorities. Therefore, Starnawski argues, exploring the contemporary nationalist discourse in 'pluralizing' societies such as Poland is no less essential for the diagnosis of anti-democratic obstacles than studying the actual conditions of minority groups themselves. The future of social and cultural pluralism in Poland heavily depends on the majority's awareness of diversity and its ability to promote attitudes of openness to and understanding of cultural differences on the one hand, and a readiness to extend the notion of 'Polishness' to a wide range of cultural and social categories on the other. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column13: Journal of Educational Psychology. Vol.95(3), Sep 2003, pp. 570-588.
column21: The structure of perceived school climate and the relationship of climate dimensions to adaptation were examined in a large-scale multi-year investigation of students who attend middle-grade-level schools. Analyses of the structure, reliability, interrater convergence, and stability of school climate ratings were conducted in a large-scale sample of over 105,000 students in 188 schools. The climate scales exhibited a stable dimensional structure, high levels of internal consistency, and moderate levels of stability over 1- and 2-year time intervals. The relationship between climate ratings and students' adjustment was examined in 3 increasingly large samples of schools and students that were collected during successive years of this project. Ratings of multiple climate dimensions were associated consistently with indexes of academic, behavioral, and socioemotional adjustment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column13: Current Opinion in Psychiatry. Vol.16(6), Nov 2003, pp. 659-660.
column21: Psychiatric trainees are often taught about the process/content distinction in working with patients, ordinarily conceived as the difference between how things are said (process) versus what is said (content) in doctor-patient relationships. The articles in this current set of reviews in Current Opinion--History and philosophy--suggest how far the process/content distinction has evolved in the past few decades and perhaps, more importantly, how the tension (creative or destructive) between the two has been compounded in a world increasingly characterized by an explosion of research findings, cultural pluralism, economic globalization, and continuous change. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column13: Self and Identity. Vol.1(3), Jul-Sep 2002, pp. 235-249.
column21: Hypotheses drawn from Taifel and Turner's (1986) Social Identity Theory and a hypothesized "need for distinctiveness" predict that attention to how two groups differ, as opposed to how they are similar, should reduce prejudice. Previous research, however, indicates that a self-awareness manipulation is needed for prejudice reduction to occur (Zarate et al, 2000). It is possible, however, that the previous self-awareness manipulations acted as self-affirmation procedures, which may complicate any interpretations. Research by Fein and Spencer (1997) based on Self-Affirmation Theory show that self-affirmation procedures enhance self-concept, which acts to reduce expressed prejudice. The present studies test hypotheses concerning a need for distinctiveness and the role of the self in prejudice reduction. 236 participants were asked to focus on between-group similarities or between-group differences, after which participants performed a self-affirmation task (Experiment 1) or a negative self-awareness task (Experiment 2). Results demonstrate that attention to group differences, in conjunction with a self-awareness manipulation, reduces prejudice. The findings are discussed for the relevance to various theories of prejudice and for models of cultural pluralism. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: (from the chapter) In this chapter, stages in the development of multicultural psychology within professional psychology are reviewed, and the controversy and dialogue that accompanied changes in curricula and institutions are discussed. This dialogue took place around some of the basic premises of multicultural psychology. Those basic premises are identified here as a culturally pluralistic philosophy, a psychosocial and sociopolitical perspective on development and treatment, and a community and systems intervention strategy in addition to individual intervention strategies. The history and theoretical bases of these premises are described and posited as an organizing metastructure for education, training, and practice of professional psychology. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: (create) Discusses the largely successful cultural pluralism that can be found in Guinea-Bissau. The country's major ethnic groups and their beliefs are described. It is concluded that the ethnographic and historical case of Guinea-Bissau opens up opportunities for inquiry into social boundary-making processes that might challenge deeply ingrained Western notions of identity formation and offer insights into nonconflictual processes of negotiating cultural differences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Civic education and changing definitions of American identity, 1900-1950. [References].
column11: Mirel, Jeffrey: U Michigan, 4114 School of Education Building, 610 E. University St., Ann Arbor, MI, US, jmirel@umich.edu
column12: Mirel, Jeffrey: U Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, US
column13: Educational Review. Vol.54(2), Jun 2002, pp. 143-152.
column21: Examines how different views of American nationalism, ideas about cultural, racial, and religious pluralism, and policies and practices about civie education have interacted in the US from 1900 to the early 1950s. Definitions of American identity changed dramatically between 1900 and 1950, challenged by millions of immigrants who came to the US early in the century. Responding to this challenge, assimilationists demanded that immigrants shed their ethnic identities entirely, while cultural pluralists emphasized maintaining ethnic roots. Although public schools created programs to "Americanize" immigrant children, that goal was realized in an ironic way as children blended their American and ethnic identities. During the Great Depression and World War II, civic education played a role in this process by encouraging students to redefine American identity as a commitment to broad civic ideals, including respect for diversity rather than strict assimilation of Anglo-American Protestant norms. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: This article compares the efforts of movement activists in three dissimilar groups to replace a stigmatized status with a valued one by portraying their groups as resembling established minorities (claims of "contiguity" in "cultural space") and as differing from groups stigmatized as deviant (claims of "distance"). The most common claims assert similarity to African Americans, and frequently incorporate civil rights themes (exemplifying frame diffusion). Tactically, these minority status claims exploit both the resonance of cultural pluralism and state recognition of minorities. Strategically, minority status framing enables stigmatized groups to claim legitimacy without changing -- simultaneously asserting both normality and difference. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column5: The Cultural Formulation: A method for assessing cultural factors affecting the clinical encounter. [References].
column11: Lewis-Fernandez, Roberto: New York State Psychiatric Inst, Unit 69, 1051 Riverside Drive, New York, NY, US, 10032, rlewis@nyspi.cpmc.columbia.edu
column12:
Lewis-Fernandez, Roberto: Columbia U, New York, NY, US

column13: Psychiatric Quarterly. Vol.73(4), Win 2002, pp. 271-295.
column21: The growing cultural pluralism of US society requires clinicians to examine the impact of cultural factors on psychiatric illness, including on symptom presentation and help-seeking behavior. In order to render an accurate diagnosis across cultural boundaries and formulate treatment plans acceptable to the patient, clinicians need a systematic method for eliciting and evaluating cultural information in the clinical encounter. This article describes one such method, the Cultural Formulation model, expanding on the guidelines published in DSM-IV. It consists of five components, assessing cultural identity, cultural explanations of the illness, cultural factors related to the psychosocial environment and levels of functioning, cultural elements of the clinician-patient relationship, and the overall impact of culture on diagnosis and care. The authors present a brief historical overview of the model and use a case scenario to illustrate each of its components and the substantial effect on illness course and treatment outcome of implementing the model in clinical practice. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: (from the chapter) Explores the politics of cultural pluralism in Tanzania and possible reasons why a degree of communal comity is evident, in contrast to nearby countries whose sociological parameters might appear similar. Main topics discussed in this chapter are: (1) precolonial Tanzania; (2) German colonialism; (3) British colonization: (4) decolonization; (5) the Zanzibar revolution; and (6) liberalization. The author discusses the difficulty of independence with respect to Tanzania. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Situating social attitudes toward cultural pluralism: Between culture wars and contemporary racism. [References].
column12: Downey, Dennis J.: U California, Irvine, CA, US
column13: Social Problems. Vol.47(1), Feb 2000, pp. 90-111.
column21: This research situates attitudes toward cultural pluralism between 2 bodies of research on socio-political conflicts with a symbolic emphasis: one addressing the culture wars and the other addressing contemporary racial attitudes. Analysis uses data from the 1994 General Social Survey (GSS) "multicultural module" to test a range of discrete claims emerging from each perspective in several thematic areas: attitudinal distribution/polarization, patterns of support/opposition and issue salience, political alignment and crystallization, and the attitudinal gap between principles and policy implementation. A recurring pattern in the data is the association of central theoretical variables with attitudinal extremity rather than (or in addition to) an association with support for or opposition to pluralism. Discussion links that pattern to the symbolic character of conflicts over pluralism and suggests how it impacts both the understanding of cultural pluralism and of symbolic conflicts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: "Half the battle"" Cultural resonance, framing processes, and ethnic affectations in contemporary White separatist rhetoric.
column12: Berbrier, Mitch: U Alabama, Dept of Sociology, Huntsville, AL, US
column13: Social Problems. Vol.45(4), Nov 1998, pp. 431-450.
column21: This paper addresses those and other issues in an examination of the "new racist" (NR) rhetoric of contemporary White separatists (WSs) who focus on legitimating their movement using a cultural pluralist master-frame. In the context of theories about social movements, affect, and the social construction of ethnicity, I describe how NRWSs engage in frame-transformation and frame-alignment by (a) consciously packaging a hate-free racism, (b) developing strategies of equivalence and reversal-presenting whites as equivalent to ethnic and racial minorities, and (c) deploying ideas about love, pride, and heritage-preservation to evidence both their putative lack of animosity toward others as well as their ethnic credentials. I interpret these ethnic affectations as contextually bound efforts at truth construction that offer an opportunity to explore the role of affect in social movements. I conclude that the product of these claims is Kultural Pluralism: a blurring of distinctions between cultural pluralism and White supremacist racism, designed to emotionally appeal broadly to moderate and mainstream conservative Whites. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Review of Business and politics in Britain.
column12: Flynn, Norman: London Business School, London, United Kingdom
column13: The Sociological Review. Vol.36(4), Nov 1988, pp. 854-856.
column17: Blackwell Publishing, United Kingdom; Sherratt Hughes, US; Sociological Publications Ltd., US; University College of North Staffordshire, United Kingdom; Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd., United Kingdom
column21: Reviews the book, Business and Politics in Britain by Wyn Grant and Jane Sargent (1987). This book, written before the 1987 General Election, is about the way business influences government in Britain with an additional chapter about business representation in the EEC. The book's thesis is that business is not well organized collectively, nor is government well placed to deal with business and therefore the government acts in ways which are contrary to the interests of business. The framework within which the analysis is conducted is essentially a pluralist one where the categories 'government' and 'business' are distinct and are the main units of analysis and the method is an empiricist account of how institutions operate. The discussion on methodology, which includes pluralism, corporatism and 'privileged interest' as alternative approaches, concludes that they in fact converge. The book is a useful descriptive account of the institutional links between various parts of business and government. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column9:

Sullivan, John L
column12: Anderson, Christopher: U Minnesota, Dept of Political Science, Minneapolis, MN, US
column13: American Educational Research Journal. Vol.34(2), Sum 1997, pp. 333-364.
column21: This study explored the views of contemporary social studies teachers on citizenship education. Q-technique was used to discern the principal conceptions held by teachers in two small samples. Minnesota teachers held 3 perspectives (cultural pluralism, communitarianism, and legalism) and teachers nationally held 4 perspectives (critical thinking, legalism, cultural pluralism, and assimilationism). Analysis of a large national sample survey of social studies teachers shoes the popularity of each perspective generally, and the characteristics of teachers who hold each perspective. Implications for citizenship education in a multicultural society are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The development and validation of an instrument to assess attitudes toward cultural diversity and pluralism among preservice physical educators.
column12: Stanley, Linda S.: U Wisconsin, Madison, WI, US
column13: Educational and Psychological Measurement. Vol.56(5), Oct 1996, pp. 891-897.
column21: Describes the development and validation of an instrument to assess attitudes toward cultural diversity and cultural pluralism. The initial instrument consisted of 60 questions and was completed by 215 preservice teachers in physical education who were enrolled in the final 2 years of their program at 11 selected universities. Factor-analytic procedures produced a conceptually meaningful four-factor solution with internal consistency reliabilities in the range of .72 to .85 for the four factors. The final instrument, the Pluralism and Diversity Attitude Assessment (PADAA), consists of 19 statements. The PADAA measures the degree to which a respondent possesses positive attitudes toward cultural pluralism and whether an individual is comfortable or uncomfortable with diversity. The 4 scales are Appreciate Cultural Pluralism, Value Cultural Pluralism, Implement Cultural Pluralism, and Uncomfortable with Cultural Diversity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.46(1), Feb,  2001
column21: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 2001, Vol 46(1), 53-55. Reviews the book "Cultural Divides: Understanding and Overcoming Group Conflict" edited by Deborah A. Prentice and Dale T. Miller (see record 1999-02753-000). Starting in 1992 a group of social psychologists, invited by the Russell Sage Foundation, discussed the implications of contemporary psychological research on culture and identity for predicting, understanding, and improving intergroup relations. The group met for six years, and this book is the fruit of these efforts. The distinguished social psychologists contributing examined four perspectives: (a) the ethnic hierarchy model, in which a dominant group claims rights and privileges not to be shared with other subordinate groups; (b) the one-way assimilation model, which requires minorities to abandon their culture and fully adopt the dominant culture; (c) the cultural pluralism model, according to which ethnic groups can maintain their distinct cultures, while adhering to a set of rules and understandings that enable them to live with other groups; and (d) the separatism model, in which culturally distinct groups withdraw from mainstream society and form autonomous, self-governing communities. This volume is particularistic: It presents very little work that purports to be universal and much that is based on cultural differences. There are many more sins of omission than of commission. Overall, this book is well worth the price. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The rhetoric of experience and the study of religion.
column12: Sharf, Robert H.: U Michigan, Dept of Asian Languages & Cultures, Ann Arbor, MI, US
column13: Journal of Consciousness Studies. Vol.7(11-12), 2000, pp. 267-287.
column21: Discusses the role of and definitions of religious experience within the study of religion. It is argued that scholarship that does not attend to the experiential dimension of religious practice is dismissed by many as reductionistic, and further, that the academic literature also does not clearly delineate between religious experience and mystical experience. The reluctance and inability of scholars to clearly stipulate the meaning of these terms is discussed in light of challenges of empiricism and cultural pluralism. Also, the ideological aspect of the appeal to experience is highlighted especially in regard to mystical experience. The role of mystical experience in Western vs Asian religious streams is explored, and evidence is examined regarding the supposition that Asian religions are more experientially rooted than their Western counterparts. It is concluded that it may be ill conceived to construe the object of religious study to be the inner experience of religious practitioners. Implications of the "humanistic" drive to empower experience are addressed in light of the need for objective reality and for critical scholarship. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
column23: objective & empirical vs subjective & cultural definitions of religious experience in academic literature

column5: Language planning and education: The case of Namibia.
column12: Dlamini, Joyce Bonisile Grace: U Illinois At Urbana-Champaign, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.61(5-A), Nov 2000, pp. 1740.
column21: This study takes issue with the assumptions underlying the Namibian English-only language policy stated in Article 3(1) of The Constitution of the Republic of Namibia (1990). The document stipulates educational provision for Namibian learners who belong to multilingual, ethnolinguistic and socio-economic groups. Since this provision results from an interaction between central government's espoused values and their perceptions of political and economic needs; the policy decision was arguably based on a reactive rather than a proactive approach to those needs. The emergence of English as the sole official language in a country of 1.6 million inhabitants, with only 0.8% speaking English natively, was therefore not planned. The study argues that first, the policy is formulated vaguely, secondly, it is a contradiction in terms with respect to cultural pluralism on the one hand, and assimilation on the other; and thirdly, that there is an apparent neglect of the learners first languages. It characterizes and discusses the nature of language-education planning, suggesting criteria considered significantly relevant in making a research-based choice using conceptual tools appropriate for language-education planning. The study further investigates the cost-effectiveness of the language policy to assess its potential success by describing and analyzing colonial language practices and the present policy in order to determine its relevancy to the needs of primary education. An alternative 3-language-formula policy plan is suggested that permits universality in primary education by promoting the use indigenous languages as media of instruction, and the incorporation of other languages as subjects, one that gives co-official status to at least one of the indigenous languages of multilingual Namibia, alongside English. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: (from the chapter) This chapter evaluates developmentalism as an ideology by presenting a series of critiques from distinct frames of reference: conservatism, neo=Marxism, cultural pluralism, feminism, and postmodernism. All 5 critiques detail the issues of developmentalism from their perspectives. They suggest, sometimes in different and incompatible ways, that developmentalism is a form of restraint. Neoconservatives see it as interfering with parents' and schools' freedom to bend children's characters from evil to virtue. Neo=Marxists see developmentalism as the ideological support for labor discipline that constrains workers' emancipatory desires. Developmentalism is presented as imposing artificial hierarchies of value on cultural patterns by pluralists. And feminists point to the demeaning nature of developmentalism that diminishes their opportunities for self=worth. Finally, postmodernism presents developmentalism as a technology of power whereby developmental discourse and practice control processes of formation of self. Developmentalism appears to be a limiting force. These differences in critique serve to affirm the social construction of developmentalism. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: (from the book) The authors contend that diversity and group identity can, under certain circumstances, be congenial to democracy and community. They report on the Intergroup Relations, Conflict, and Community Program, a circular and living-learning program aimed at helping students understand the relationship between groups and democracy. The program incorporates elements of many psychological approaches to improving intergroup relations but also focuses more heavily than most approaches on difference and on making group boundaries salient. The chapter examines the impact of this program on intergroup perceptions, attitudes, and behaviors. It also examines the role of preexisting power differentials, hypothesizing that group identity is threatening for members of dominant but not of subordinate groups. The research reported here attests to the importance of both of these factors, serving as an experiment in cultural pluralism. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: (from the book) Describes the varying forms that ethnic relations have taken in US history. The description is organized around 4 models: ethnic hierarchy, one-way assimilation, cultural pluralism, and group separatism. These models have both descriptive and normative significance: each represents the form that relations between ethnic groups have taken at some time and place in the US and also serves as an ideal-type model of the form these relations might take in the future. The author argues that cultural pluralism is the most promising of these alternatives. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Going beyond cultural pluralism: Science education for sociopolitical action. [References].
column12: Hodson, Derek: U Toronto, Ontario Inst for Studies in Education, Toronto, ON, Canada
column13: Science Education. Vol.83(6), Nov 1999, pp. 775-796.
column21: Some guiding principles of antiracist education are combined with Vygotskian notions of education as enculturation in order to produce a set of proposals for a radical form of multicultural science education for sociopolitical action. Major educational goals include: raising participation and attainment levels in science for students from ethnic minority groups; and sensitizing all students to racism, and other forms of discrimination and oppression, in science and technology, science education, and contemporary society. This article outlines a radical form of curriculum development, involving the politicization of teachers, as the only effective way of implementing such a curriculum. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract).

column13: Cushner, Kenneth [Ed]. (1998). International perspectives on intercultural education.  (pp. 259-300). xii, 387 pp. Mahwah, NJ, US: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates Publishers; US.
column21: (from the chapter) Describes the development of multicultural education in the US. The authors discuss the foundations of multicultural education in America, including cultural pluralism, population diversity, and segregation. The authors also provide a history of a segregated society and schooling, touching on the Anglo-Protestant roots of segregated schooling, schooling for the American Dream, and the 20th-century crisis of identity. The authors then discuss common schooling and segregation at the end of the millennium. This topic includes discussion of decentralization and financing of public schools, inequality of school performance by region, urban vs rural environment, and by racial and ethnic status. Schooling for groups by race and culture is discussed. The integration of multicultural education into schools is described, focusing on multicultural education policies, teacher education, and approaches to and theories of multicultural education in the US. A case study of multicultural reform in 1 school is provided to illustrate the authors' points. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The self-transformations of African American achievers.
column12: Hemmings, Annette: U Cincinnati, Educational Foundations Program, Cincinnati, OH, US
column13: Youth & Society. Vol.29(3), Mar 1998, pp. 330-368.
column21: Ethnographic case studies of 3 African American student achievers attending desegregated urban high schools are analyzed in terms of theories in the new cultural pluralism in educational anthropology. The achievers are described as they sought to transform their "multiple selves" as Black persons, as women and men, and as members of social classes in transition between the "multiple worlds" of their families, schooling, and peers. They accomplished their self-transformations through the use of contrasting strategies of self-negation, self-fragmentation, and self-synthesis that were adapted in response to conflicting cultural expectations. This investigation offers crucial insights into the nature and consequences of the identity work of African American youths in urban educational contexts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: (1997). Multicultural counseling in schools: A synergetic approach. xxi, 320 pp. Alexandria, VA, US: American Counseling Association; US.
column21: (from the cover) As the percentage of ethnic minority students in schools continues to increase, school counselors and counselors-in-training must broaden their cultural knowledge base and develop new strategies that are responsive to the complex challenges these students face. This text provides direction for working within the ethnic minority student's worldview and identifies synergetic and developmental interventions that meet their needs. The author discusses the relationship of changing school demographics to socioeconomic and psychoeducational imperatives; the balance between universalism and cultural pluralism within the schools; the resilience of ethnic/cultural student groups; and ethnic and cultural status as stressors on the normal development of youth. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: White racial consciousness and preference for counselor ethnicity in White undergraduate students.
column12: Summerson, Mark Thomas: Washington State U, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering. Vol.57(11-B), May 1997, pp. 7238.
column21: This study (a) explored the viability of the White Racial Consciousness (WRC) model and the associated instrument (i.e., Oklahoma Racial Attitude Scale-Preliminary Form or ORAS-P), (b) examined the status and process of White racial identity development (i.e., the prevalence of WRC types, the relationship between WRC type and preference for counselor characteristics, the relationship between type and gender), and (c) provided information about White client preferences for counselor characteristics, including counselor ethnicity, in anticipation of increasing cultural pluralism. This was accomplished by (a) using the ORAS-P to determine 300 White undergraduate students' WRC type, (b) assessing and rank ordering student preferences for 14 different counselor characteristics, and (c) examining the relationship between WRC type and preferences for counselor characteristics. The ORAS-P was found to be a reliable instrument, but, evidence for the construct validity of the WRC model was inconsistent. As hypothesized, more than 70% (i.e., 82%) of students preferred an ethnically similar counselor to an ethnically dissimilar counselor. Further, students' preferences for counselor characteristics were in the expected rank order (i.e., similar attitudes/values, more education, similar personality, older) and very similar to those of students of the same and different ethnicities in other similar studies. There was a high correlation between the rank orderings of preferred counselor characteristics among the WRC types with all types showing most preference for the same three characteristics (i.e., similar attitudes/values, more education, similar personality). There was also a high correlation between male and female rank orderings with the same four characteristics ranked highest by both genders (i.e., similar attitudes/values, more education, similar personality, older). Prior counseling experience was found to have no relationship to either preference for ethnicity or counselor characteristics in general. Support for the hypothesized relationship between student WRC type and preference for counselor ethnicity varied by mode of analysis. Support for the hypothesized relationship between students' gender and WRC type was supported regardless of the mode of analysis. These findings suggest that the WRC model and the ORAS-P require additional validation prior to application and that similar counselor ethnicity is preferred less than other counselor characteristics among (a) White undergraduate students regardless of WRC type, gender, or prior counseling experience and (b) undergraduate students regardless of ethnicity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: (from the chapter) The goal of this chapter is to present a broad overview of the past, present, and future of ethnic psychology in the US. Discussion covers the following 4 areas: 1. define ethnicity and outline related issues; 2. present a brief overview of the historical experiences of different ethnic groups in the US as a background to facilitate understanding of ethnic relations in this country (both racism and discrimination characterize the historical relationships between white and nonwhite ethnic groups); 3. describe the past and present psychological models that attempt to explain different ethnic differences, including the inferiority model, the deficit model, cultural pluralism, symbolic racism, and human diversity; and 4. outline the challenges that face ethnic researchers in psychology. The major ethnic minority groups discussed are African Americans, Hispanic Americans, Asian Americans, and Native Americans. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Preservice physical educators' attitudes toward cultural pluralism: A preliminary analysis.
column12: Stanley, Linda S.: U British Columbia, Dept of Curriculum Studies, Vancouver, BC, Canada
column13: Journal of Teaching in Physical Education. Vol.16(2), Jan 1997, pp. 241-249.
column21: Developed the Pluralism and Diversity Attitude Assessment (PADAA) instrument to assess attitudes toward cultural diversity and pluralism among preservice physical educators. 15 US universities were selected as test sites for validation. Five to 42 college students completed the PADAA at each institution; 215 responses were used for analysis. Results indicate that preservice physical educators may respect and value cultural diversity, but because scores decreased as the level of intensity of the scales increased, preservice students may be less likely to implement culturally sensitive teaching practices to meet the individual needs of all students. Findings suggest that teacher educators should work toward not only sensitizing prospective teachers to culturally diverse students, but need to guide and encourage these future educators in adopting and implementing educational programs that are responsive to cultural diversity. To accomplish this goal, it is recommended that teacher educators specifically provide opportunities for preservice students to implement pluralistic teaching practices. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Multicultural education: The views of three contemporary African American theorists.
column12: Haddad, Daphne Wharton: U South Carolina, US
column13: Dissertation Abstracts International Section A: Humanities and Social Sciences. Vol.56(12-A), Jun 1996, pp. 4643.
column21: Public schools have always experienced more social, cultural, and ethnic pluralism among students than among teachers, administrators, and policy makers. Several conceptualizations of ethnic diversity have influenced schools, including assimilation defined as Anglo-conformity, assimilation defined as "melting pot," and cultural pluralism. Since the 1960s, multicultural education has become an umbrella term for a variety of approaches to ethnic and cultural pluralism. James A. Banks of the University of Washington, Carl A. Grant of the University of Wisconsin, and Asa G. Hilliard III of Georgia State University are three contemporary African American theorists who have been writing about multicultural education since the 1960s. Six questions are posed of their published work: (1) How is multicultural education for schools defined? (2) What are the implications of multicultural education for curriculum and instruction? (3) How are individual and group rights and responsibilities defined and related to each other? (4) What are the implications of multicultural education for human relations within schools? (5) What are the implications of multicultural education for the structural organization of schools? (6) What justification for multicultural education is offered through empirical, historical, and philosophical analysis? In the final chapter, a critical analysis of the work of James Banks, Carl Grant, and Asa Hilliard locates them within the broader context of multicultural education research in the United States. Banks' typologies of Ethnic Revitalization Movements and Stages of Ethnic and Cultural Development, and his identification of five dimensions of multicultural education are important theoretical contributions to multicultural education research. Although he is as critical of educational inequity as are Grant and Hilliard, Banks views multicultural education as consistent with the American democratic tradition and argues that a core of common values derived (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Diversity in Classrooms: An Important Response.

column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.39(8), Aug,  1994
column21: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1994, Vol 39(8), 843. Reviews the book, Promoting Diversity in College Classrooms: Innovative Responses for the Curriculum, Faculty, and Institutions by Maurianne Adams (Ed.) (1992). This collection of readings provides an important response to the challenge of diversity in the academy. The book is divided into three major sections: New Perspectives on Teaching and Learning, Social Diversity in the Curriculum, and Cultural Pluralism and Core Curricula. The first section introduces a model in Chapter 1 that describes four critical dimensions of learning and teaching that affect diverse student bodies. The second section highlights social diversity in the curriculum and begins with Noronha's thesis that the relationship between multicultural and international education needs to be discussed and debated within the context of campus diversity. The final section presents the reader with an overview of the experiences and issues different types of institutions encounter as they implement change in response to shifting campus demographics. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1994, Vol 39(10), 950-953. Reviews the books, African American Psychology: Theory, Research, and Practice edited by A. Kathleen Hoard Burlew, W. Curtis Banks, Harriette Pipes McAdoo, and Daudi Ajani ya Azibo (see record 1992-98690-000) and Black Families at the Crossroads: Challenges and Prospects by Robert Staples and Leanor Boulin Johnson (see record 1992-98862-000). The first book probably can be profitably read in isolation without an "interpretator," but for maximum understanding it should be studied by means of lively small group discussion with informed teacher input. Of course, as the society evolves toward cultural pluralism, it is increasingly important that others besides African American psychologists access and use the provided concepts and methods, and we would encourage these efforts through cooperative team-teaching strategies. In contrast, the second book is highly readable, though it emphasizes the use of statistical and survey data to substantiate ideas more than the reporting of discrete, focused empirical studies. This book, because it is a useful overview of theories about Black families--including mate selection, parenting, and community support--could be an excellent background to the more specific studies and ideas presented in first book. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: (from the introduction) "Inside the Mixed Marriage" is about the personal experiences of people in mixed marriages. . . . Here the marital partners consider the changing sets of advantages and constraints mixed marriages have imposed on them and their children. And, in addition to discussing the impact of society on [their] marriages, [they] speculate on the impact [their] marriages have had on the attitudes of others. It is the view from inside the mixed marriage which makes these [personal] narratives significant. They provide sharp contrasts to those who understand mixed marriages solely in the context of intergroup relations, social control, and social dominance. They hit directly at popular myths and fears. These narratives illustrate the artificiality of social constructs like ethnicity, race and culture. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Racial/ethnic diversity in doctoral programs of psychology: Challenges for the twenty-first century.
column12: Highlen, Pamela S.: Ohio State U, Dept of Psychology, Columbus, US
column13: Applied & Preventive Psychology. Vol.3(2), Spr 1994, pp. 91-108.
column21: Contends that changing demographics and accompanying cultural pluralism pose challenges to psychology departments in terms of multicultural curriculum, generation of culturally sensitive research and theory, and representation of racial/ethnic minority students and faculty. The impact of the European-American worldview as the foundation of the dominant culture is explored as it relates to psychology. Implicit and explicit examples of ethnocentrism, which reflect the imposition of the dominant culture on other cultures, are offered. Universal psychology is challenged for the 21st century as culture-bound and is subsequently viewed as nonexistent. Organizational and individual multicultural development models are advanced, along with specific strategies for how doctoral programs can embrace diversity through commitment to structural change and inclusion of paradigms that reflect alternate worldviews. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Revue Francaise de Psychanalyse. Vol.57(3), Jul-Sep 1993, pp. 891-898.
column21: Notes that anthropological thought generated by the cultural pluralism of the environment appears to nourish psychoanalytic thought in its wake. The analytic situation is an example of the interaction of 2 different cultures. Access to interpretation of the meaning of the patient's discourse transcends the simple decoding of a linguistic message; it implies the sharing by the 2 participants of prelinguistic semantic elements. This action exposes interpretation to the risks that may result from a countertransferential privilege accorded by the analyst to the manifest but deceptive character of same-culture-type of the situation. This theme is illustrated by 2 clinical examples (a same-culture and a different-culture S). (English, German, Spanish & Italian abstracts) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column16: University of Calgary/Dept of Sociology; Canada
column21: Examined ethnic variations in informal caregiver networks (CGNs) by testing the utility of the cultural pluralism and social class models. Data came from 2 surveys that form the 1982 National Long Term Care Survey (B. Phillips et al, 1986). Ss were 737 informal helpers (aged 14+ yrs) who assisted an elderly respondent in 6 activities including eating and dressing. Ss were 11.6% German, 12.6% Irish, 11.3% English, and 13% African-American. As income increased, CGN size decreased. Cultural but not class artifacts affected the structure of CGNs. CGN composition was associated with marital status, sex, and living arrangements among African-Americans and activity level among English-Americans. All White groups were more likely to rely on immediate family for care, while African-Americans turned to others outside the immediate family. (French & Spanish abstracts) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: (from the publicity materials) This study focuses on Asian-American elderly in a large midwestern city to examine the problems related to the development, delivery, and utilization of the services sponsored by Title III of the Older Americans Act (OAA). The findings show that there are six major variables in attracting Asian-American elderly clients to OAA services: convenient location, the presence of Asian staff and board representation, activities conducted in Asian languages, a bicultural staff aware of Asian-American elderly's special needs and values, bilingual staff workers, and programs that meet the unique needs of the target population. The author recommends that federal, state, and local governments encourage social agencies to have more Asian-American board and staff members and service providers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: (from the book) [This book looks] into the theoretical perspectives, both sociological and psychological, of ethnic minority identity and . . . [reviews] the empirical work done on ethnicity. Part II of this book will first look at what constitutes an ethnic minority group. It will then go on to investigate the sociology of ethnicity from assimilationism to cultural pluralism. Next, we will look at the psychological theories of ethnic minority identity. In Part III, research issues on ethnicity will be examined, covering areas such as styles of cultural adaptation, strategies of self-categorization, and levels of self-esteem among members of ethnic minority groups. Finally, the implications of these findings will be examined in relation to the integration of ethnic minority groups in Britain. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: Examined the extent to which bureaucratic, innovative, and supportive organizational cultures coexist in different hierarchical levels and different functional units of 8 large public accounting firms. The degree of creativity among 122 individuals in different organizational positions and units was also examined, and the relationship of culture to creativity and other job-related variables was analyzed. Ss completed various questionnaires, including the Remote Associates Test. As hypothesized, organizations exhibit cultural pluralism along the lines of hierarchy. Organizational culture was significantly related to hierarchical level, with the top level of management perceiving the culture of the organization as significantly more innovative and supportive than either middle level management or lower level accountants. column5: Cultural communication and intercultural contact.
column12: Carbaugh, Donal: U Massachusetts, Dept of Communication, Amherst, MA, US
column13: (1990). Cultural communication and intercultural contact. xix, 439 pp. Hillsdale, NJ, England: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc; England.
column21: (from the introduction) This is a book about communication in cultural contexts, its meaningfulness to situated participants, the local forms it takes, and the moral orders created as participants interact socially. The chapters in the book explore how communication displays membership in communities, as well as the dynamics involved when persons from one community contact those from another. This book has three main parts, with each addressing questions at the forefront of cultural communication inquiry. The first part explores how some communication patterns give voice to culture through the construction, and evaluation, of cultural identities. Part II explores moments when culture patterns of communication contact one another, with special attention given to interactional sources of asynchrony. And, the third part is concerned with comparative study of cultural patterns, exploring how communication theory can achieve a cross-cultural utility without losing its cultural sensitivity. Each part of the book includes three main sections. First is a chapter that introduces the part. . . . The heart of each part includes readings that report original field work about communication patterns, by authors who have lived them. . . . Finally, and rather unusually, each part includes original epilogues to the field work reports that typically include reflections of the authors on their work, but sometimes includes commentary by another. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Forked tongue: The politics of bilingual education.
column12: Porter, Rosalie Pedalino: Newton Public Schools, Bilingual & English as a Second Language Programs, Director, Newton, MA, US
column13: (1990). Forked tongue: The politics of bilingual education. xiii, 285 pp. New York, NY, US: Basic Books; US.
column21: (from the jacket) "Forked Tongue" is a devastating inside account of how the twenty-year-old experiment in bilingual education has failed our language-minority children-and why. Rosalie Porter, a distinguished educator who herself entered the American school system with no English, draws on local, state, and international experience to provide us with the first authoritative account of which policies, programs, and practices actually succeed with the children they are intended to serve. Without for a moment denying that language-minority children need special assistance, she argues forcefully that such assistance must first bring them into the mainstream of American education. And she shows concretely how this can be done without loss of cultural identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: U.S. race relations in the 1980s and 1990s: Challenges and alternatives.
column12: Thomas, Gail E.: Texas A & M U, Dept of Sociology, Professor, College Station, TX, US
column13: (1990). U.S. race relations in the 1980s and 1990s: Challenges and alternatives. xxiii, 281 pp. Washington, DC, US: Hemisphere Publishing Corp; US.
column21: (from the preface) This volume is designed to assess the nature and progress of American race relations in the 1980s and to make projections about trends and proposals for the 1990s. In discussing the nature of race relations in contemporary society, the volume reflects a social-structural rather than a psychological or social-psychological approach. The current status of U.S. race relations is examined here in terms of (a) the educational, social, and economic progress of racial minorities in contrast to that of the majority group and (b) the extent to which desegregation and ethnic diversity have been achieved in present-day U.S. society. Again, our focus is quite different from that of earlier studies, which concentrated on racial attitudes rather than on racial behavior and racial progress. Most of the chapters assume a power-conflict perspective that emphasizes structural relations and power dynamics between majority and minority groups. The volume focuses on the three most underrepresented racial minorities in the United States: blacks, Hispanics, and American Indians. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: Outlines the origins of community psychology (CMP) in the US and its development in New Zealand at the University of Waikato (UW). CMP is seen as a specific subdiscipline within psychology, having a distinctive conceptual orientation, an explicit value base, and an emphasis on research methodologies compatible with applied research. Three general themes are relevant to the UW conceptual orientation of community psychology: an ecological approach, competence enhancement, and prevention. Explicit values guiding CMP interventions include: empowerment, diversity and cultural pluralism, social innovation and evaluation, community development and participation, and collaboration. Research methods that give a primary emphasis to qualitative data are elaborated. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Cross-national research in sociology.
column12: Kohn, Melvin L.: Johns Hopkins U, Professor of Sociology, Baltimore, MD, US
column13: (1989). Cross-national research in sociology. 424 pp. Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; US.
column21: (from the introduction) By contrast [to other types of cross-national research], this book will focus on cross-national studies in which, to borrow from Erwin Scheuch's (1967) apt phrase, nation is context. In such research, one is primarily interested in testing the generality of findings and interpretations about how certain social institutions operate or about how certain aspects of social structure impinge on personality. My rationale for the first part of the book is the most self-evident: this is a set of papers dealing with general theoretical and methodological issues in cross-national research. Most of the remaining chapters-more than half of the book-use nation as the "context" for inquiry. These analyses investigate whether social processes that occur in one nation or one type of nation are similar to or different from social processes that occur in other nations or other types of nations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The Future of the Death Penalty in America. [References].
column12: Bedau, Hugo Adam: Center for the Study of Decision Making, Tufts University, Medford, MA, US
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.33(7), Jul,  1988
column21: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1988, Vol 33(7), 573-575. Reviews the books, The Ultimate Coercive Sanction: A Cross-Cultural Study of Capital Punishment by Keith F. Otterbein (see record 1987-97481-000) and Capital Punishment and the American Agenda by Franklin E. Zimring and Gordon Hawkins (see record 1987-97425-000). Contributions by social scientists to the debate over the death penalty in this country have been confined largely to close scrutiny of two major issues: whether the death penalty as actually employed is a deterrent (and, especially, whether it is a better deterrent than imprisonment) and whether its use is arbitrary and discriminatory (especially against racial minorities). These two books break new ground and complement each other in their orientation. Zimring and Hawkins propose a version of cultural pluralism to characterize the death penalty in the United States. Otterbein begins his volume with a complaint against his fellow social scientists to the effect that they "have avoided conducting any studies that might show the social functions of capital punishment". He proposes to remedy this lack by examining data in the Human Relations Area Files on nearly three dozen (mostly primitive) cultures. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: Asserts that character training has been regarded as somewhat disreputable but that the qualities of determination, carefulness, concentration, self-restraint, patience, conscientiousness, and endurance are each different aspects of personal capability that children need to acquire. The author analyzes and indicates the educational importance of each of these qualities within the categories of endeavor, heed, and control, which are regarded as qualities of will (i.e., the effort of striving). It is suggested that from this perspective teachers need to pay particular attention to the relative insignificance of cultural pluralism and to the importance of the teacher's role as model and guide through difficulty. column5: Disruptive school behavior: Class, race, and culture.
column12: Hanna, Judith Lynne: U Maryland, Senior Research Scholar, MD, US
column13: (1988). Disruptive school behavior: Class, race, and culture. xix, 246 pp. Teaneck, NJ, US: Holmes & Meier; US.
column21:
(from the cover) Unique in its honest confrontation with real problems and its challenge to many assumptions and practices in education and public policy, this book rests on the conviction that equal opportunity in formal education is necessary but not sufficient to enable students to achieve socioeconomic success in adult life. The author demonstrates the importance of social relations that are not restricted to the classroom, such as mutually shared values and communication patterns. By focusing on the clash of socioeconomic styles that often coincides with desegregation, Hanna offers explanations for aggressive and other disruptive school behavior and then presents coping strategies for parents, teachers, governments, the private sector, and concerned citizens. "Disruptive School Behavior" illuminates widespread educational problems on a national scale.
(from the preface) This book is written for educators (including parents); for students of public policy, communication, social interaction, urban problems, ethnic relations, American studies and play; and for all those individuals in a variety of institutions attempting faithfully and in good will to equalize equal opportunity and justice. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Group Analysis. Vol.20(2), Jun 1987, pp. 157-166.
column21: There is often an unwillingness to correlate the technique and the philosophy of the group therapist. Those nations which have a generally homogeneous population are able to use techniques which may be considered non-invasive and appear to be able to accomplish a good deal of clinical progress. The USA, my native land, a collection of fifty states and territories, with a population that migrated from many shores, is the site of many competing techniques of clinical intervention. These clinical interventions mesh with the heterogeneity of the country. Indeed, the cultural pluralism that is so much a part of the fabric of the USA is wedded to many of the group psychotherapy techniques that are at work in the USA. Let us contrast the USA with those Latin American or European nations where the majority of the people profess the same religious beliefs or where the overwhelming majority believe in the same political process. In that situation, clinical technique is closely tied to a particular philosophy of life. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: Journal of Contemporary Psychotherapy. Vol.17(3), Fal 1987, pp. 203-216.
column21: When ethnic working-class women seek psychotherapy, the process can place them in a double bind in that their personal striving threatens their ethnic and class ties. Clinical material illustrates sociological myths related to the ethnic "melting pot," cultural pluralism, and female liberation as well as common symptoms such as achievement anxiety, veneration of authority, religious conflict, experiential limitations, and a feeling of being the "black sheep" of the family. By challenging their own ethnic, racial, and class identities, clinicians can open up new treatment possibilities to help strengthen positive group identity, enhance self-esteem, and support personal striving in their patients and in themselves. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
