column5: Changes in racial stereotypes among college students.
column12: Maykovich, Minako K.: Sacramento State Coll
column13: British Journal of Social Psychiatry & Community Health. Vol.6(2), 1972, pp. 126-133.
column21: Examined the changes in stereotypical images of whites, blacks, and Japanese between 1932 and 1970. Using the same method as the pioneer study of D. Katz and K. W. Braly, 100 white, 100 Japanese, and 100 black male and female university students were asked to choose the 5 traits from a list of 84 attributes that they deemed most characteristic of each racial group. Results were compared to similar studies conducted since 1932. It was found that the image of whites, predominantly one of progressivism, individualism, and intelligence in previous testing from 1932 to 1960, changed in the 1970 testing to an emphasis on materialism and hedonism, especially in the eyes of politically active Japanese American Ss. The classical primitive image held of the blacks from 1932 to 1950 contrasted with the 1970 image of aggressiveness and straightforwardness along with their persistent trait of musicality. The Japanese image had emerged in 1970 as ambitious, industrious, loyal to family, reserved, and quiet. The greater degree of stereotypy among racial images which in the 1930's tended to support white ascendancy has become more diversified to accommodate the changing ideological transformation from white ascendancy to cultural pluralism. (35 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Some dominant perspectives in the literature relating to multi-racial social work.
column12: Denney, David: Mid-Kent Coll, Chatham, England
column13: British Journal of Social Work. Vol.13(2), Apr 1983, pp. 149-174.
column21: Provides a framework for the understanding of the social work literature relating to racial minorities. Four main themes are identified: the anthropological approach, liberal pluralism, cultural pluralism, and the structuralist position. Race relations goals of the anthropological approach are assimilation and integration; of the pluralist approach, integration and social mobility for minorities; of the structural approach, removal of racism through structural change. Relationships among the literature, social work practice, and ultimate race relations goals are discussed. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).
column23: approaches to multiracial social work literature

column5: Research in multicultural societies: Implications of cross-cultural methods.
column12: Berry, John W.: Queen's U, Kingston, Canada
column13: Journal of Cross-Cultural Psychology. Vol.10(4), Dec 1979, pp. 415-434.
column21: In recent years there has been a dramatic rise in the number of comparative studies of groups within culturally plural nation states. There are 2 models that may serve as frameworks for guiding such research-the unicultural and the cross-cultural. An argument is advanced that research in plural societies requires a new model, one that draws primarily upon the cross-cultural model, reflecting an ideology of cultural pluralism, so that the independence and uniqueness of each group in the comparison may be respected. A transethnic model is proposed for conducting comparative studies of ethunits in polyethnic societies. Guidelines for assessing issues of comparability, group independence, and the number of groups in the comparison and their cultural characteristics are discussed. (29 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Review of Studies in English to speakers of other languages and standard English to speakers of a non-standard dialect.
column12: Arthur, Bradford: University of California at Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, US
column13: Language Learning. Vol.22(1), Jun 1972, pp. 143-146.
column21: Reviews the book, Studies in English to Speakers of Other Languages and Standard English to Speakers of a Non-Standard Dialect edited by Rodolfo Jacobson (1971). The book is intended to encourage on the part of classroom English teachers an acceptance of cultural pluralism recognition of the value of the cultural and linguistic backgrounds of minority-group students. Much of the writing on the education of Black children emphasizes the differences and contrasts between standard and Black English. Such writing frequently concludes that English textbooks basic readers and spellers in particular-should be redesigned to build from the language norms students bring to the school setting. A somewhat different view is presented by the author who reports a study of the speech of five Black children. The children he studied used a mixture of non-standard and standard dialect variants. Unmarked plural and possessive, for example, were less frequent than the marked, standard variants. In the decade ahead, applied linguists may be called upon to help classroom teachers recognize and teach those children whose language norms are neither identical with nor totally different from the standard, school norms. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Multicultural beginnings and early learning.
column12: Wieseman, Robert A.: Auburn U, Montgomery, AL, US
column13: Journal of Instructional Psychology. Vol.13(4), Dec 1986, pp. 172-176.
column21: Discusses issues associated with cultural pluralism in the early educational environment of childcare services. Young children must be made aware of the importance of their cultural and racial backgrounds, and teachers and policy makers must be made aware of special academic and social interventions designed to integrate minority and majority students. Focusing on each child's uniqueness and individuality is an excellent method of emphasizing the importance of cultural pluralism. Learning styles related to specific ethnic groups must also be dealt with by educators. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The influence of German-language culture on Freud's thought. [German].
column13: Jahrbuch der Psychoanalyse. Vol.19 1986, pp. 15-35.
column21: Traces the eclectic linguistic and cultural influences that played a paramount role in shaping Freud's background and psychoanalytic thought. Freud exploited the conceptual and expressive nuances and peculiarities of the German language to describe the perversely polymorphous fantasies of childhood (e.g., voyeuristic, masochistic). He used English and French words, sometimes with a German prefix or suffix, in connection with those aspects of the self that Freud experienced simultaneously as familiar and mysterious. He used Latin and Ancient Greek words and mythological figures and legends to formulate his theories and the Unconscious (e.g., interpretation of dreams). According to the author, psychoanalysts need a linguistic and cultural pluralism in their background similar to Freud's, which provides the intermediary thoughts, or compromise formations for their preconscious elaborations. (German & English abstracts) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Police in a plural society.
column12: Loree, Donald J.: Canadian Police Coll, Ottawa
column13: Canadian Police College Journal. Vol.9(4), 1985, pp. 391-412.
column21: Discusses the concept, dimensions, and implications of pluralism as it relates to ethnicity, religion, language, age, sex, marital status, income and occupation, education, and political and organizational affiliations of the Canadian people. The impact of pluralism on the police is viewed as direct (when interest groups endeavor to influence police) and indirect (demographic changes that occur as the population shifts or ages). It is suggested that police must come to grips with their role in a diverse and changing society, which is affected by their generally conservative stance toward social change. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Contemporary South Asian women in the Canadian mosaic.
column12: Naidoo, Josephine C.: Wilfrid Laurier U, Waterloo, Canada
column13: International Journal of Women's Studies. Vol.8(4), Sep-Oct 1985, pp. 338-350.
column21: Assessed unfavorable attitudes of White Canadians toward South Asian (SA) immigrants by examining value differences between the 2 cultural groups. Expectations were viewed in the context of 2 models of ethnic integration: the Anglo conformity model and the cultural pluralism model. In Study 1, 2-session interviews were conducted in the homes of 105 SA women and a matched group of 105 White women. In Study 2, 76 females and 65 males (primarily students) who were White responded to a questionnaire. Data show a duality in the SA women's attitudes: traditional with respect to family, religion, and marriage but contemporary regarding education and opportunity. Their selective cultural outlook met with limited social approval by White Canadians. The latter favored integration toward Anglo-Saxon norms and values rather than the cultural pluralism of official Canadian policy. (30 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Value of cultural pluralism to the generalizability of psychological theories: A reexamination. [References].
column9:
Kagehiro, Dorothy K

Mejia, Juan A

Garcia, Joseph E
column12: Kagehiro, Dorothy K.: U Wisconsin-Parkside, Behavioral Science Div, Kenosha
column13: Professional Psychology: Research and Practice. Vol.16(4), Aug 1985, pp. 481-494.
column21: Argues that the limited generalizability of psychological theories and hypotheses may stem, in part, from a restricted sampling of psychological theorists and investigators and hence from the homogeneity of their background assumptions, biases, and values. Threats to generalizability at the hypothesis-testing, theory-development, and hypothesis-formation stages of research are discussed using examples from the literature. A cultural pluralism approach is recommended for the recruitment and training of socioculturally diverse psychologists, capable of conducting research in a wider variety of settings with a wider range of Ss. Types of short- and long-term location and recruitment techniques are discussed, and the promotion of the cultural pluralism perspective within the graduate curriculum is addressed. (3 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The wandering IQ: American culture and mental testing.
column12: Cravens, Hamilton: Iowa State U, Program in History of Technology & Science, Ames
column13: Human Development. Vol.28(3), May-Jun 1985, pp. 113-130.
column21: Reviews the history of the studies of IQ that took place at the Iowa Child Welfare Research Station in the 1930's and 1940's, which suggested that the IQs of young children could be dramatically boosted or depressed under specified environmental conditions. It is argued that the Station's scientists arrived at their conclusions primarily because they responded to larger, if often tacit, ways of perceiving reality programmed into American culture itself. It was in the mid-1920's that cultural pluralism and cultural relativism came into their own as important cultural and intellectual movements. It was in those years that the final phases of the heredity-environment controversy were taking place, and the Station scientists argued for the importance of the social environment in the development of IQ, and they were critical of the excesses of the mental testing movement. The scientists later became involved in campaigning for a national system of preschool education and in conducting research with children in state institutions. These projects led the researchers to consider themselves as part of the child welfare profession, rather than part of academic psychology. (42 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Cultural unity, cultural pluralism and the school: Toward a pedagogical synthesis.
column12: Reagan, Timothy: Gallaudet Coll
column13: Journal of Research & Development in Education. Vol.18(2), Win 1985, pp. 21-25.
column21: Argues that the debate in contemporary American education between those advocating the "liberal" cultural ideal and those who support the "multicultural" ideal for public schooling may be somewhat less dichotomous in nature than is generally believed. Differences between the 2 viewpoints in their conceptions of culture and educational goals are discussed. It is concluded that seeing the 2 viewpoints as complementary product and process goals allows the adoption of the positive pedagogical features of the anthropological sense of culture found in multicultural education, as well as the benefits of the liberal cultural idea. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Cultural Pluralism in Mental Health Training.
column12: Jackson, Anna M.: University of Colorado School of Medicine, Denver, CO, US
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.29(8), Aug,  1984
column21: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1984, Vol 29(8), 664-665. Reviews the book, Mental Health and People of Color: Curriculum Development and Change by Jay C. Chunn II, Patricia J. Dunston, and Fariyal Ross-Sheriff (Eds.) (1983). The challenge of cultural pluralism in mental health training is faced boldly in this book. It represents an ambitious effort to assess shortcomings in the sensitive area of mental health education for four racial groups, by practicing clinicians who are members of these racial groups. The avowed purpose of the book is to provide both a state-of-the-art assessment of curricula in the respective mental health care areas and a format for incorporating vital cultural data into the core mental health professions. Although the writing styles vary, the book is highly readable and easily understood. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Anglo-native relations in Australia, New Zealand and the USA.
column12: Havighurst, Robert J.: U Queensland, Brisbane, Australia
column13: Educational Research Quarterly. Vol.8(4), 1984, pp. 103-112.
column16: U. of Southern Calif. Sch. of Educ; US
column21: Examines the interaction of Western culture with primitive cultures in what are now Australia, New Zealand, and the US. Relations between Anglo emigrants and the Aborigines, the Maoris, and the American Indians are traced. It is concluded that Anglo-Native relations point to assimilative and acculturative forces, and that, despite the wrongs inflicted on the language and culture of these native groups, there are signs that these societies are moving toward acceptance of cultural pluralism. column5: Ethnicity: The search for characteristics and context.
column12: Bernstein, George: Montclair State Coll
column13: Theory Into Practice. Vol.23(2), Spr 1984, pp. 98-103.
column16: The Ohio State University Press; US
column21: Discusses definitive characteristics and contexts that typify ethnic groups, noting that the recent resurgence of interest in ethnic groups has produced work reflecting the search for adequate concepts and definitions. S. Thernstrom (1980) suggests 14 characteristic features of ethnic groups. Additional characteristics of ethnic groups are conscious group membership, biological relatedness, common descent, and secondary characteristics. Larger contexts for understanding ethnicity include nationality, assimilationism, cultural pluralism, and stages of ethnicity. Types of ethnicity are identified as tribal, adaptive, and revivalist. Implications of ethnicity for multicultural education are discussed. (19 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
column23: characteristics of ethnic groups

column5: The concept of cultural pluralism: Issues in special education.
column12: Poplin, Mary S.: Claremont Graduate School
column13: Learning Disability Quarterly. Vol.6(4), Fal 1983, pp. 367-371.
column21: Proposes that, within the field of education, cultural pluralism (CP) offers the right of every American child to maintain his/her identity with home and community socialization experiences. CP rejects the deficit model, which holds that children from minority culture (MC) backgrounds often come to school with cultural and linguistic defects that must be remedied. It is not suggested that English is not to be a part of the curriculum, but it is suggested that English acquisition should be an additive process, not a replacement. In terms of special education, CP is a factor because many MC children are placed in special education due to cultural, linguistic, and/or racial differences. In many public schools, cultural differences are still translated as deviant, deficient, disabled, and/or disadvantaged. For lack of a better label, many are identified as learning disabled. For those MC students who do have handicaps, the issue of cultural differences is as pertinent to their education as the issue of their learning disabilities. The problems associated with identifying disabilities in MC youngsters are complicated by a lack of understanding of the various cultures; discrimination associated with referral, assessment instruments, and placement; and the virtual nonexistence of teacher training and certification programs that combine special and bilingual/multicultural education methods. (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Sociocultural guidelines for clinicians in multicultural settings.
column12: Moffic, H. Steven: Baylor Coll of Medicine, Houston, TX, US
column13: Psychiatric Quarterly. Vol.55(1), Spr 1983, pp. 47-54.
column21: Presents a set of sociocultural guidelines for clinicians to use in caring for patients from multiple ethnic backgrounds. It is noted that the increasing cultural pluralism of the US means that clinicians are more likely to encounter patients from such backgrounds. Principles of cultural psychiatry include consideration of differences in child rearing, cognitive styles, social networks, sex roles, symptom expression, and concepts of mental health and illness. Cultural differences in verbal and nonverbal communication must be understood to prevent treatment-affecting misunderstandings. It is suggested that cultural self-analysis by the clinician is necessary to alleviate countertransference problems. The difficulties of developing definitive cultural knowledge are noted. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
column23: sociocultural guidelines for patient care, clinicians working in multicultural settings

column5: Counselling in cross-cultural perspective.
column13: International Journal for the Advancement of Counselling. Vol.6(2), 1983, pp. 83-92.
column21: Presents the opening address to the 18th Round Table for the Advancement of Counseling held in Lausanne, Switzerland. The author discusses the ethical responsibility of counselors and therapists to know their clients' cultural values and the relative importance of universals in human culture vs cultural variations. It is noted that both of these tenets must be kept in the counselor's frame of reference, a difficult task in light of the extensive and complex social changes taking place throughout the world. The importance of cultural pluralism and the search for a positive cultural identity has paralleled the global acceptance of and desire for technological change. Examples of the harmonious integration of these developments, such as in Japan, and of cultures where conflict has arisen, such as among Blacks in Africa, are presented. Four qualities-empathy, skill in communication, sensitivity, and willingness to inform clients about the nature of the counseling process-are regarded as important for therapists and counselors in this context. Techniques for training counselors to be effective in cross-cultural situations are outlined. The particular problems encountered by foreign students in adapting to their new environments are described, and research projects designed to address these issues are proposed. (10 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Education and cultural pluralism: An intercultural action/activity experiment in a migrant setting. [French].
column12: Koykis, Fanny: Free U of Brussels, Belgium
column13: Revue Belge de Psychologie et de Pedagogie. Vol.45(181-182), Mar-Jun 1983, pp. 25-30.
column21: Introduced activities with immigrant children at the pre-primary level using the children's own drawings and stories about family, vacations, holidays, customs, and country. This proved a springboard for discussion about causes of immigration and problems of assimilation-important to the children who existed daily within the 2 cultures of home and school. Feedback among teachers, parents, and children encouraged self-expression and self-growth and fostered a positive psychosociological environment for individual growth. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Ethnic minority issues in psychology: A reexamination. [References].
column12: Sue, Stanley: U California, Los Angeles
column13: American Psychologist. Vol.38(5), May 1983, pp. 583-592.
column21: Argues that 2 tasks need to be addressed in view of psychology's growing commitment to cultural pluralism in research, theory, and professional practice: The 1st is that ethnic minority group issues are analogous to antinomies in which cherished values and principles are pitted against one another and need to be recognized as such. These paradoxes are evident in at least 5 conflicts: emic vs etic studies, mainstreaming vs pluralism, equal opportunity vs equality of outcome, modal personality vs individual differences, and presence vs absence of racism today. Attempts to find a single, permanent solution are fruitless; the resolution of these issues should be an ongoing process requiring divergent reasoning and diverse solutions. The 2nd task involves the acquisition of power and influence, since means for implementing proposed solutions are necessary. A brief history is provided of ethnic minority efforts in the governing structure of the American Psychological Association. It is suggested that the search for diverse solutions and the attainment of institutionalized influence are vital in increasing pluralism. (39 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column21: Reviews recent literature related to cultural and social influences on guidance and counseling and discusses how these factors have an impact on the career guidance process in the contemporary world of cultural pluralism. The socialization process is critically important to career development. Family influences, social class, and sex-role stereotyping influences have been studied in many countries. Political ideologies have both a cultural and a legal effect on career guidance programs. Schools reflect dominant society values. Societal changes (e.g., as a result of development or unemployment) offers a catalyst for career guidance. (36 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Human migration and the acculturation of minorities.
column12: Smither, Robert: Johns Hopkins U
column13: Human Relations. Vol.35(1), Jan 1982, pp. 57-68.
column21: Majority-minority relations have historically taken the forms of elimination, segregation, fusion, assimilation, or pluralism. Cultural pluralism, the dominant ideology in the world today, is based on the assumptions of tolerance on the part of the majority and a willingness to learn on the part of the minority (acculturation). It is argued that modern theories of acculturation have tended to neglect the importance of individual differences in the process of adaptation. The socioanalytic model based on psychological role theory and studies of natural language is presented. It offers a model of acculturation that accounts for individual differences as well as the situational factors that affect acculturation. (47 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
column23: socioanalytic model of human migration & acculturation of minorities

column5: Creating a culturally pluralistic classroom: Theories and practice.
column9:
Rodriguez, Ana M

Plank, Carmen C
column12: Rodriguez, Ana M.: San Diego State U, Coll of Education
column13: Spanish Speaking Mental Health Research Center Monographs. Vol.Mo 8 1981, pp. 35-44.
column16: Spanish Speaking Mental Health Research Center; US
column21: Provides educators with specific suggestions for creating classrooms in which all manifestations of a student's culture are valued, tapped, and encouraged. The approach is to introduce several variables in "implicit" culture that, if not understood by the teacher, can result in negative consequences for the student. Examples of teacher-student dissonance are cited primarily from ethnographic classroom studies. Pragmatic suggestions are made in the form of methods and activities. It is contended that only through the deliberate application of theory and research findings will teachers promote cultural pluralism and provide successful conditions for the culturally and linguistically different student. (6 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Communal and pietistic identification as related to size and concentration of Jewish population.
column12: Gordon, Leonard: Arizona State U
column13: Journal of Psychology & Judaism. Vol.5(1), Fal-Win 1980, pp. 28-37.
column21: Drawing on the National Jewish Population Study of 1970-1971, the authors make the following conclusions: (a) There is a core of pietistic (i.e., those who strictly adhere to religious practices), Jews, particularly in the New York City area. (b) There is considerable cultural pluralism within Jewish communities. (c) There are generic points of Jewish identification. (d) A high degree of Jewish/non-Jewish formal and informal interaction, particularly in newer communities, raises questions about the future degree of communalistic Jewish identity in predominantly nonpietistic environments. (22 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.23(4), Apr,  1978
column21: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1978, Vol 23(4), 261-262. Reviews the book, Counseling with Mexican American Youth: Preconceptions and Processes by Richard R. DeBlassie (1976). This is a book, if read carefully, that could make a difference in the practices of counseling with people of Mexican ancestry. Sprinkled throughout this book is common-sensical and data-based information on characteristics and needs of individuals of Mexican ancestry. Two pages on standardized testing and similarly brief sections on bilingual issues, psychiatric classification problems, educational concerns, and others are so short as to be almost misleading. This book represents an important beginning by a warm and sensitive psychologist. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Pastoral ministry between the times.
column12: Gerkin, Charles V.: Emory U
column13: Journal of Pastoral Care. Vol.30(3), Sep 1976, pp. 178-185.
column21: Discusses how changes in society are forcing pastoral counselors to re-evaluate their roles while maintaining their Christian commitment. Cultural pluralism and value confusion create situations where the minister's ongoing dialogue with his tradition can offer a stabilizing force within change. Examination and clarification of conflicting values can liberate persons both from old compulsions labeled "Christian" and from new social pressures disguised as "liberation." The pastoral counselor must be keenly aware of these values and their roots. He must relate to persons who live in different cultural frames; this requires sensitivity, reflection, and re-examination of past value concepts. Three case histories illustrate the need for culturally transcendent values to stabilize human relationships and establish a functional identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column12: Castaneda, Alfredo: Stanford U
column13: Atisbos.  Sum 1975, pp. 79-91.
column21: Early educational theory about the bilingual child was conditioned by "melting pot" ideology and by the Anglo-American conformity orientation of psychologists. The goal of democratic cultural pluralism is biculturalism. The degree of assimilation of an ethnic group is reflected in different socialization processes that stress different learning and motivational preferences. Recent developments in educational biculturalism emphasize the importance of understanding preferred modes of communication, motivation, and learning among ethnic groups at different levels of assimilation. (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Needs assessment and cultural pluralism in schools.
column12: McNeil, John D.: U California, Los Angeles
column13: Educational Technology. Vol.15(12), Dec 1975, pp. 25-28.
column21: Approaches needs assessment in such a way as to encourage multicultural orientations. Phases in the process of needs assessment are specified which can be used at many societal levels. Cultural pluralism is viewed as an appreciation of ways in which different peoples satisfy universal needs. It involves learning how to become familiar with unfamiliar cultures (e.g., how to classify objects, ideas, and problems in general categories). A partially contrived example is given of needs assessment for cultural pluralism at the school level in a Mexican-American community. It illustrates formulation of goals, setting goal priorities, identification of enabling goals, translating goals into educational plans and instruction, and selection of measures and techniques for assessing the present status of the learner. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Ethnic group members and the correctional system: A question of human rights.
column13: Canadian Journal of Criminology & Corrections. Vol.16(1), Jan 1974, pp. 35-52.
column21: Considers that the equitable treatment of ethnic minorities in correctional institutions is not a political, administrative, or legal problem, but rather a question of human rights. Intergroup relations are discussed in terms of the concepts of ethnocentrism, socio-cultural intolerance, and the minority's coping processes, cultural pluralism and assimilation, which manifest themselves in intergroup relationships. The relation between minority group membership and psychological, sociocultural, and psychocultural deviance is considered. The major issue is thought to be the individual's right to receive treatment consistent with his cultural identity and needs. Recommendations for correctional workers are presented, and the questions of the dominant group's responsibilities to the minority are discussed. (French abstract) (66 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: The First--Thoughtful and Exciting.
column12: Sarason, Seymour B.: Yale University, Psycho-Educational Clinic, New Haven, CT, US
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.18(7), Jul,  1973
column21: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1973, Vol 18(7), 340-341. Reviews the book, Man as the Measure: The Crossroads edited by Daniel Adelson (1972). In this book, the editor describes the ideas and social forces that have given rise to the shift from clinical psychology's and psychiatry's traditional treatment model to a community psychology concerned with social systems, community processes, and prevention. Man, he points out, has a need to experience the sense of community, but there is much in the history and traditions of our society that prevents this, not the least of which are the facts of cultural pluralism. At the same time that ethnic, racial, and religious factors provide some basis for experiencing "community," they are also sources of group conflict. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Therapist, Patient, and Cultural Milieu.
column12: Dudek, Stephanie Z.: Universite de Montreal, Montreal, PQ, Canada
column13: PsycCRITIQUES. Vol.18(6), Jun,  1973
column21: Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1973, Vol 18(6), 275-277. Reviews the book, Psychotherapy and Culture Conflict in Community Mental Health. 2nd ed by Georgene H. Seward (1972). The overall perspective of this book is that of the majority middle-class therapist who must face the complexity of minority group mental health and must come to recognize cultural pluralism as a necessary good. The dangers and pitfalls of therapy without understanding the patient in his cultural milieu are emphatically outlined. The need to distinguish pathological conflict is stressed. Seward presents many suggestions about the suitability of types of therapy for different cultural groups, such as the questionable use of long-term insight therapies with lower-class patients who present attitudes toward time that stress immediacy. She indicates the usefulness of folk medicine, suggestion, and ritual in crisis intervention and in cases where more formal therapeutic methods could not possibly bridge the communication barriers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Mass society, mass media and the transformation of minority identity.
column12: Singer, Benjamin D.: U. Western Ontario, London, Canada
column13: British Journal of Sociology. Vol.24(2), Jun 1973, pp. 140-150.
column21: Synthesizes elements from traditional conceptions of communications and asks whether contemporary mass media, particularly TV, might be a force for differentiation rather than homogenization, revolutionary change rather than conservatism, and creation of a new identity rather than production of an identity crisis. The development of black consciousness among American Negroes is used as an example of the influence toward cultural pluralism exerted by TV. The former identity of the Negro, largely bound to interpersonal relationships on a local level, has been weakened by a rise in distrust and fear of violence in the ghetto. Concurrent with the resulting turning inward is an increasing reliance on TV, both for information about the outside world, and for development of a "symbolic community" to replace the lost interpersonal community. The co-occurrence of these 2 processes has contributed significantly to the heightened black consciousness. It is suggested that future developments in mass communications may have similar effects on other interest groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Jews as an ethnic minority in the United States.

column21: Describes ethnic minority and the exclusion of Jews as an outgroup as a function of ethnocentrism on the part of the dominant group and in terms of the symbolic interaction system of overt affiliation, covert identification, and societal identification. The history of anti-Semitism in the US from the colonial period to the present and the change in stereotypes of Jewishness are reviewed. Jewish reactions to prejudice and discrimination are outlined in terms of 8 factors: (a) feelings of anger and pain, (b) avoidance and withdrawal, (c) hypersensitivity, (d) self-hatred, (e) self-isolation, (f) assimilation, (g) cultural pluralism, and (h) militancy and protest. (29 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Changes in racial stereotypes among college students.
column12: Maykovich, Minako K.: Sacramento State Coll
column13: Human Relations. Vol.24(5), Oct 1971, pp. 371-386.
column21: Reviews previous studies of racial stereotypes and compares changes with current stereotypes. A sample of 100 white, 100 black, and 100 Japanese students at Sacramento State College were administered the same instrument as in the 1932 Katz and Braly study. In earlier studies whites had been described as intelligent, ambitious, industrious, materialistic, and pleasure-loving. In 1970 white traits emphasized were materialistic, pleasure-loving, straightforward, and ambitious. Earlier studies of black stereotypes held them to be superstitious, slovenly, religious, happy-go-lucky, ignorant, and pleasure-loving. The 1970 image had shifted radically to include aggressiveness and straightforwardness along with the persistent black trait of musicality. The Japanese stereotypes of intelligence, industriousness, and progressiveness showed a relative lack in consensus, but in 1970 showed greater stereotypy than in earlier studies. By 1950 racial images had become more diversified and less stereotypical, reflecting the changing ideology from white conformity to cultural pluralism. Current tendencies reveal a trend toward reverse racism, re-emphasizing racial distinctions which had previously become blurred. (35 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).

column5: Cultural pluralism and linguistic equilibrium in Switzerland.

column13: American Sociological Review. Vol.16 1951, pp. 157-163.
column21: Cultural diversity commonly is the rallying point for conflict within European nations; the linguistic pluralism in Switzerland is a striking exception. The equilibrium among the 4 national languages of Switzerland originated before language became a symbol of nationalism and has been maintained by demographic factors-differential fertility among the language groups, offset by trends in internal migration-and political measures designed to prevent language groups from attaining a minority status. column5: The interaction of ethnic groups: a case study of Indians and whites.
column12: Aginsky, Burt W.: CC N Y, New York.
column13: American Sociological Review. Vol.14 1949, pp. 288-293.
column21: Using results of a field study of the Pomo (Calif.) Indians as an example, 3 types of interpopulational participation are considered: (1) amalgamation (total participation), which was opposed by both whites and Indians, (2) cultural pluralism (negative participation), which was accepted verbally by both, and (3) dominance-submission (restrictive participation), accepted verbally by a majority of older white residents. "In cases where both groups are opposed to the three types of solutions, there remains but one realistic program, namely a conscious program of ever-increasing functionally integrated participation." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved).
